'''Sidney Siegel''' (4 January 1916 in [[New York]] – 29 November 1961) was an [[United States|American]] [[psychology|psychologist]] who became especially well known for his work in popularising [[non-parametric statistics]] for use in the behavioural sciences.  He was a co-developer of the statistical test known as the [[Siegel–Tukey test]].

Siegel completed a  [[PhD|Ph.D.]] in Psychology in 1953 at [[Stanford University]].  Except for a year spent at the [[Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences]] at Stanford, he thereafter taught at [[Pennsylvania State University]], until his death in November 1961 of a coronary thrombosis.

His parents, Jacob and Rebecca Siegel, were Jewish immigrants from [[Romania]].<ref>Sidney Siegel (ed. Samuel Messick, Arthur H. Brayfield), ''Decision and Choice'', p.2. McGraw-Hill, 1964</ref>
